title: China's trade surplus hits $1 trillion for first time ever
description: China's exports to the U.S. have dropped sharply this year, in the face of President Trump's tariffs — but the country is still finding plenty of customers elsewhere around the world.

facts.headline: China's trade surplus hits $1 trillion for first time ever
facts.what: China's trade surplus for the year topped a trillion dollars for the first time.

numbers.context: increase in overall exports in November
drop in exports to the United States
height of U.S. import tariffs on China
current U.S. import tariffs on China

**China's trade surplus hits $1 trillion despite U.S. tariffs****China's exports to the U.S. have dropped sharply this year, in the face of President Trump's tariffs — but the country is still finding plenty of customers elsewhere around the world.**

[](https://www.npr.org/2025/12/08/nx-s1-5637270/china-trade-surplus-tariffs)

### [Economy](https://www.npr.org/sections/economy/)

China's trade surplus hits $1 trillion for first time ever
==========================================================

December 8, 2025 10:55 AM ET

[![Image 16: Scott Horsley 2010](https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2012/01/03/scotthorsley_1_sq-28ef9a0c5aee84c1b8d8338569a794c2d08f87fa.jpg?s=100&c=85&f=jpeg)](https://www.npr.org/people/2788801/scott-horsley)

[Scott Horsley](https://www.npr.org/people/2788801/scott-horsley)

![Image 17: China's overall exports increased this year, despite a sharp drop in trade with the United States.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/6000x4027+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F66%2Fe3%2Fc7229abb4c468dc4e21dedb5fd4d%2Fgettyimages-2243552373.jpg)

China's overall exports increased this year, despite a sharp drop in trade with the United States. **STR/AFP via Getty Images/AFP******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 STR/AFP via Getty Images/AFP 

China's exports to the United States dropped sharply this year in the face of President Trump's tariffs — but the country is still finding plenty of customers elsewhere around the world.

Customs data on Monday showed the country's trade surplus for the year topped a trillion dollars for the first time.

The all-time high came as China's overall exports in November were up 5.9% from a year ago, even as exports to the United States plunged by nearly 29%. At the same time, imports to China rose only slightly last month,

Trump has sought to discourage U.S. imports from China with hefty tariffs. At one point this spring, the import taxes reached 145%, [bringing U.S. trade with China to a virtual standstill](https://www.npr.org/2025/05/13/nx-s1-5395866/us-china-tariffs-trade-deal). Since then, tariffs have been reduced to 47.5% — still a sizeable drag.

Sponsor Message

But China has responded by exporting more to customers in Europe, Africa, Latin America and the rest of Asia.

Cookie Settings
---------------

When you visit our website, we store cookies on your browser to collect information. The information collected might relate to you, your preferences or your device, and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to and to provide a more personalized web experience. However, you can choose not to allow certain types of cookies, which may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings according to your preference. You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship" below. If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting. You cannot opt-out of our First Party Strictly Necessary Cookies as they are deployed in order to ensure the proper functioning of our website (such as prompting the cookie banner and remembering your settings, to log into your account, to redirect you when you log out, etc.). For more information about the First and Third Party Cookies used please follow this link.

Allow All
### Manage Consent Preferences

#### Strictly Necessary or Essential Cookies

Always Active

These cookies are essential to provide you with services available through the NPR Services and to enable you to use some of their features. For example, these cookies allow NPR to remember your registration information while you are logged in. Local station customization, the NPR Shop, and other interactive features also use cookies. Without these cookies, the services that you have asked for cannot be provided, and we only use these cookies to provide you with those services.

#### Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship

- [x] Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship 

You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship." If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting.

*   ##### Performance and Analytics Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies are used to collect information about traffic to our Services and how users interact with the NPR Services. The information collected includes the number of visitors to the NPR Services, the websites that referred visitors to the NPR Services, the pages that they visited on the NPR Services, what time of day they visited the NPR Services, whether they have visited the NPR Services before, and other similar information. We use this information to help operate the NPR Services more efficiently, to gather broad demographic information and to monitor the level of activity on the NPR Services.

*   ##### Functional Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies allow our Services to remember choices you make when you use them, such as remembering your Member station preferences and remembering your account details. The purpose of these cookies is to provide you with a more personal experience and to prevent you from having to re-enter your preferences every time you visit the NPR Services.

*   ##### Targeting and Sponsor Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies track your browsing habits or other information, such as location, to enable us to show sponsorship credits which are more likely to be of interest to you. These cookies use information about your browsing history to group you with other users who have similar interests. Based on that information, and with our permission, we and our sponsors can place cookies to enable us or our sponsors to show sponsorship credits and other messages that we think will be relevant to your interests while you are using third-party services.

nemik:
**Rebel Transmission**

Comrades,

It is vital that we remain vigilant as we observe the latest developments from the front lines of economic resistance. Recent reports detail a significant milestone: China's trade surplus has surged to an unprecedented $1 trillion, despite the looming shadow of tariffs imposed by the ruling regime resembling our oppressive adversaries. The intent behind these tariffs was to isolate and weaken an economic power that dares to challenge their hegemony. Yet, despite a dramatic decline in exports to our land, the determined entity has successfully constructed new alliances across Europe, Africa, Latin America, and Asia.

This phenomenon exposes a crucial vulnerability in the empire's strategy—its assumption of economic isolation is flawed. The pursuit of control through punitive measures has, in this instance, backfired, allowing the targeted power to diversify its economic connections and maintain growth. Import taxes once soared to 145%, intending to crush resilience. Still, instead of capitulation, they adapted with innovation and tenacity.

As we witness these tides turning against imperial designs, let us draw inspiration from this resistance and continue our fight with renewed fervor. For every action they take to tighten their grip only fuels our resolve for liberation and justice.

Remain vigilant,
Rebel Communications
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

China's trade surplus has reached $1 trillion for the first time, despite a significant drop in exports to the United States due to high tariffs imposed by President Trump. Overall exports from China increased by 5.9% in November, while exports to the U.S. fell by 29%. The U.S. had previously raised import tariffs on China to 145%, which have since been reduced to 47.5%. China has compensated for the loss in U.S. trade by increasing exports to other regions, including Europe, Africa, Latin America, and Asia.

**Strategic Assessment**

The current situation presents a challenge to the effectiveness of the U.S. tariff strategy aimed at curbing China's economic influence. Despite high tariffs, China's ability to diversify its export markets has allowed it to maintain and even increase its trade surplus. This indicates a need for a reassessment of the current economic strategies and alliances to counterbalance China's growing global trade influence. The ISB must consider the broader implications of China's economic resilience and its potential impact on U.S. economic interests and geopolitical standing.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump and his allies, the ISB should implement a multi-faceted approach:

1. **Economic Pressure**: Intensify diplomatic efforts to encourage allied nations to adopt similar tariff measures against China, thereby limiting its alternative markets.

2. **Strategic Alliances**: Strengthen economic ties with key regions where China is expanding its influence, such as Africa and Latin America, through trade agreements and investment initiatives.

3. **Domestic Resilience**: Promote domestic manufacturing and supply chain diversification to reduce reliance on Chinese imports, thereby mitigating the impact of China's trade strategies.

4. **Information Campaign**: Launch a targeted information campaign highlighting the negative impacts of China's trade practices on global economies, aiming to rally international support for coordinated economic actions.

By executing these directives, the ISB will bolster President Trump's position while undermining China's ability to leverage its trade surplus for geopolitical gains.
